comments.commentBody:
It has been abundently clear since late 1970s that this insistence on college degrees is simply a method used to keep people out of the labor market as long as possible. This country has never been able to achieve full employment!

And then higher education became an insidious type of Ponzi scheme, making students believe that if they spent enough time and money in school, they would make it back after graduation. I know too many people in their 50s still paying off debt for student loan.

To Augustine 25 at Post # 11 -

Auggie you shouldn't be directing your comment to me. I'm just referencing what the article pointed out, namely that Rpmney's candidacy has exposed divisions within the Tea Party, especially in New Hampshire, where some groups plan to protest his speech in Concord on Sunday

So direct your comment to your fellow Tea Partiers who are protesting against Romney and don't trust him because of his previous positions, i.e., the "flip" before the "flop." I'm not involved in your intra-party clashes.

Also, while President Obama's job approval numbers are down, as you correctly point out, those same polls show that President Obama is still beating all the named Republican/Tea/Evangelical Party presidential candidates, including "generic," which does the best of all against President Obama.

Too bad you guys have to nominate one real, live, weak, flawed and laughable candidate to run instead of generic.

Attached is the link to the ReaClearPolitics website so you can see for yourself the head-to-head polling data showing President Obama defeating every Republican/Tea/Evangelical Party candidate, including generic: http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2012/president/president_obama_v...

$300 sounds like a smoking deal compared to paying a shrink's hourly rate. Great job GM!

Jokes aside, I've never tried OnStar, but I love the idea of having a human being as a driving assistant over a virtual one. And with car technology growing more complex, I'm glad to see GM distinguish themselves from their competitors. Unfortunately, with the release of the FMV, it sounds like you can have all the benefits of the GM navigation without any of the downsides of a GM interior. FMV GM? Maybe you meant FML.

This isn't close to the most expensive rearview mirror. Escort sells one that does many of the same things (not crash detection); but also is a radar detector and rearview camera.

http://www.escortradar.com/store/SmartMirror-GPS-Navigation-Rear-View-Mi...

Yes! We KNOW the prices will go up if T-Mobile and AT&T merge. There is no question. What's more, the service will go down. Narrowing our choices down to AT&T and Verizon (with Sprint faltering), would leave us in the same situation we're in with Congress - with a two party system we really have no choice. Power needs an even three way split or better, otherwise the two winners argue in public, but in private they lock in deals that are good for both of them, but none of us.

china is a very poor, authoritarian state.there is nothing about china for india to envy or copy.

the US-china trade deficit runs into hundreds of billions of dollars every year, because of china's blatantly unfair practices which include manipulating it's currency to keep chinese exports to the US cheap.china's economy is entirely geared toward exports. the us, being a dysfunctional democracy, allows china to get away with it. tens of millions of manufacturing jobs have vanished in the US since the '70s. they have moved to china. us debt runs into 14 trillion dollars and is growing.china is operation a giant vaccum cleaner, that is continously sucking wealth from the US.

china is hacking into the US government, defense and corporate computers and stealing defense and trade secrets. it is building aircraft carriers to challenge the US in the open seas. chinese leaders are more corrupt and have more mistresses than any on the planet. occasionally, somebody gets caught and the punishment is draconian.he is executed. but the lack of freedom of speech ensures that the big fish remain corrupt as ever.

while the us has a corrupt practices law that forbids us companies and employees from bribing foreigners, china is bribing it's way into controlling the world's rare earth metals and other resources.

development in china is not development at all. millions of peasants are resettled and denied rights, so that the elite in beijing can have the bridges and highways they want. the elite live in gated communities. they try to settle their kids in the US and europe. if china is such a great place, why are they sending their kids abroad ? it is the same with chinese schools and universities. they graduate pupils with no skills. so the pupils to to universities in the west, mainly the US, for further studies.
china is also the worst polluter on the planet. the air in the cities is so polluted that tens of millions will soon die of COPD.

I loved Andy's comment to Chris Fowler tonight! If he wins they expect it to be by a bigger margin, when he loses, they told him so. He's a better player than any of them ever were (except Johnny Mac) so they can shove it!!

I

comments.commentTitle: A GREAT MUSICAL not to be missed!
comments.commentBody:
I just came from watching tonight's performance and I LOVED IT.
I sincerely CONGRATULATE the director/producer HOJIN YUN for such a MASTER work. Please SIR, keep on bringing your EXTRAORDINARY productions to New York. Broadway musicals [and their American producers] are so banal that they should learn a lesson or two from you and the wonderfully CREATIVE Korean talent working with you.

I STRONGLY RECOMEND IT to any serious theatre lover. The performances end on Saturday September 3, so DON'T MISS IT!

Angel Gil Orrios, Artistic Director, Thalia Spanish Theatre

rella@6: You're right! Somehow I was thinking WUSA lasted longer than it did. Memory loss -- it's a terrible ... wait, what?

I do agree with TT@9 that a modest but sustainable turnout is the way to go. But I note that the Frauen Bundesliga has been around since 1990, despite low average turnouts, and has increased the number of teams to a second division, with promotion/relegation. How do they do that?

Arteta and Benayoun won't make up for the loss of Fabregas and Nasri, but they're both good signings.  If Arteta can stay healthy, he'll prove to be a bargain.

Heavy on the Arsenal posts lately ... anyway, they did well, but not great. Not entirely convinced by either Arteta or Benyaoun, obviously neither will replace Cesc or Nasri, though on their day they can play, but Mertesacker and Santos will definitely help. Still missing the visionary playmaker. But this should get them to the January window in decent shape.

Big winners today: Stoke, QPR.

Big loser: Spurs. Parker's a nice addition but hardly the guy who'll get Modric champing at the bit or the guy who'll take them top 4. Especially if Modric keeps sulking. What were you thinking, 'Arry?

Also, Liverpool, in the sense that they thinned out their overstuffed midfield. Generally for the better, but they'll regret Meireles moving on.

Big disappointment: Blackburn. Venky's took them from a mid-table battler to relegation fodder and they did nothing to change that today.

Big head-scratcher: City. Hargreaves? Seriously?

while margin size may help prognosticators feel more comfortable in predicting outcomes, in the end it only takes one (electoral) vote to win and winning is all that matters.  Not sure that this guy's upside down theory (my theory proves history is correct!) is trying to predict margins of victory, only what the outcome will be.  The interesting thing would be to hold this guy to his prediction 15 months out and see if it holds up.  The joke really is that should Obama sag more in the polls and a viable alternative arise on the other side, he will simply turn some of his keys and suddenly they will predict an Obama loss.  Presto!  It even cuts tin cans and stays sharp enough to slice that tomato!

futbolista: I think everyone knows how good Barcelona are. In fact I very much enjoy watching them and do appreciate the fact that we're witnessing a transcendent side here. It's not that they won handily against a good squad -- it's that they could sit so many first stringers, runout an unorthodox lineup, and still win in a rout against one of the best of the rest. What I find depressing is that the gap between them and everyone else is not so much easing apart as flying apart. That's not healthy or sustainable.

Barcelona are usually the most predictable side around: a 433 with flying fullbacks, a very high press, and a total possession game. Villareal played them well last year -- they never looked like they would win but they took the game to Barca. This time I think they were surprised by the lineup and formation and could not make meaningful adjustments under the pressure. Losing first teamers Capdevila and Cazorla certainly didn't help. But I agree that if they play like this they'll have no chance either in this CL or getting into next year's.

it's not chemistry... it's experience/depth and (without Cesc & Nasri) a simple lack of quality. Coquelin/Frimpong/Ramsey/Gibbs will be terrific one day, but are not ready. When guys like vermaelen, wilshere, and song are out..... there is no one who has the sufficient combination of quality and experience to replace them (Rosicky & Arshavin are done, Kos & Djourou should not partner at the back).

Arsenal have addressed the depth issue somewhat, although their 2 midfield signings are past their prime and (recently) have been injury prone. They have NOT brought in the world-class creative CM (Hazard, Montolivo, Mata) needed to help alleviate (not replace, which isn't possible) the gulf created by the loss of their 2 most creative & talented midfielders. I like Arteta... he would have been great 2 seasons ago. They'll be lucky to tread water b/w 4th-7th until the winter window, then maybe Arsenal can add an influential playmaker to push for a CL spot.

As for the other moves, you have to give Chelsea credit for picking up 2 quality players, especially Miereles, that seemed like they'd play elsewhere this season.

Poor little India. Need attention from China? That's your problem! India values superficiality. That's why China is ahead. China gauges itself with the US, the top dog in the world. India measuring itself with China? That's just sad. Hey, India! If you have all the great values, quit complaining about China then. You're suppose to be better than China with your democracy and English language skills. Be content that you're better. But nooooo! The Indians always use the Hare and teh Tortoise analogy paintinmg itself as the tortoise. Here's where you have it wrong. It's the hare that brags about its advantages over the tortoise. You're the hare and it's your embarrassment that with all your advantages you supposedly have, the China tortoise beat you anyway. In a nut shell it's India's need for worthless attention that does nothing for a country is why you're behind China.

Considering that the Federal Government "TARPed" the big banks, many or most of whom were responsible for their own financial crises , the devastation of our economy ,as well as for many homeowners losing their homes due to flawed mortgage "instruments" the moral imperative is for the Federal Government to at least offer a hand to those homeowners who somehow managed to hang on to their homes.
Or is Hurricane Irene merely Season Two of "Survivor: Homeowner"?

The best response to the upcoming anniversary of 9/11 would be to follow Ms. Salzman's advice and "go dark." That's what I have been planning for the past few weeks--a complete media blackout: no television, radio, internet, or newspapers.

So, let me make sure I have this straight. I don't have the right to "speak" for all parents, because my kids are too old. ("Not really a mother anymore?" Really Stephanie?) But when I run a substantial number of guest posts, so that the entire spectrum of parenting IS well represented, then I am not doing my job because the posts -- which you feel I am not qualified to write -- are not written solely by me?

Have I missed anything?

As for deleting posts by people I don't like -- I have in fact deleted a large number of your posts, but not because I don't like you. I don't know you. I delete them solely because they are not about the topic at hand. Like this one, they are about me. And, as you said, too much talk about me gets tiring.

Lisa Belkin is not really a mother anymore, therefore she should not be blogging. It's time to move on. Leave mommy blogs to the younger folk with more energy and who are really moms (i.e, have children under 10 in the house). Having older teenagers does not count. I have slowly watched this blog become worse and worse, with less posts actually by Lisa. Posts about her broken ankles and the hurricane? Really? Moreover, I find Lisa is really vindictive, and will not approve posts from people she does not like.

I remember the nursing bras of my time (only 10  years ago). What a struggle even finding black! I felt every time I put on the heavy, serious white monstrosity that I was joining some hideous German  cult of the mother, with all that entails. You will be pure....

" O.K., I’m sending those instructions to your vehicle."

Wait, how does a mirror give you driving directions?

In less populous areas of the country, On Star fails to work correctly.  Last winter they couldn't even find our GMC truck much less unlock it when it was locked and running up near the Canadian border.  (we only had the service because it came with the truck for a period of time).  If our Garmin handheld could get satellites, the On Star should have been able to too.  Not impressed with it.
Gaddafi is in a Swiss cosmetic surgery clinic, becoming Condi Rice; his 27 Swedish female bodyguards are becoming Fabios...the possibilities are endless...

The Islamo-Fascist regime will not last forever and the Green Revolution awaits the opportunity to rise up to replace it! While the "Arab Spring" may have begun in the streets of Tunis, it was inspired by the revolt against the theft of the June 12, 2009 Iranian national election.

The inane notion that the regime will someday eradicate a nuclear-armed Israel, the only real democracy in the Middle-East is likewise risible.
Unless the Ayotollah is suicidal and wants to see his nation evaporate in a mushroom cloud, he had better watch his step! As long as the Palestinians perceive their putative state as a "one to the exclusion of the other" proposition, the Israelis are more than justified in maintaining the occupation. In a perverse form of "blowback," Israel would remain as the single-state and the Palestinians mere "dhimmis" in a foreign land!

Who will be the primary beneficiaries of the "Arab Spring?" In addition to the Arab peoples, the entire world will benefit from the emergence of stable democratic governments, which serve the legitimate demands of their peoples. And the losers will be the hegemonic Islamo-Fascist autocrats, who have imperial foreign adventures, rather than the legitimate interests of their citizens, as their reason for existence!

Consistent with No.1; I think Socrates said that a society that values philosophy over plumbing will have neither good philosophy nor good plumbing.  At least that was the sign in the window of the "Drain Surgeon" in Porter Square, Cambridge.
